The maximum rotation speed, in degrees per second.

The hour range this NPC is awake for. Can be the full daytime for things that don't sleep.
Which NPC type groups to alert when entering combat.
Range within which an NPC is willing to investigate reports of an attack or other event.

Whether to use the Combat Action Evaluator via an accompanying CombatConfig. This completely replaces all other combat behavior but still uses movement properties such as strafe durations and move speeds.
The range for absolute minimum time before an NPC can execute a second attack (or block).
The range for absolute minimum time before an NPC can execute a second attack.
The time delay range between consecutive attacks
Weight for the direct combat movement behavior (i.e. just going straight at the target, maintaining a close distance and attacking. Set to 0 to disable.
Weight for the combat movement behavior where the NPC will always charge at you while attacking. Set to 0 to disable.
Weight for the combat movement behavior where the npcs will always chharge at you,put 0 to disable.
Weight for the combat strafing movement behavior. Set to 0 to disable.
The time delay range before the NPC performs an attack, provided it's in attack range.
The time delay range after the NPC performs an attack, provided it's in attack range.
An optional macro element for supplying more bespoke combat movement behavior. Weight for the behavior must be internally defined in the macro element.
Relative chasing speed when pursuing a target.
Relative speed to use during combat when backing away from target.

How long the NPC should actively search for its lost target before giving up and going back to idle.
Percentage chance to engage in combat if another flock member engages a target.

How long to strafe for when in the alerted state. Only applies if MaintainDistanceWhileAlerted is true.
How frequently to strafe when in the alerted state. Only applies if MaintainDistanceWhileAlerted is true.

This is for handling all the damage/enemy/etc sensors that are common to most states and take priority over everything else

We use two reset states so that when switching from a secondary behaviour we don't reset the primary random idle. All Instructions with a Once that needs resetting within this state should be mentioned here.

If target is too close for too long, try to retreat a bit.
We start a timer when entering attack mode to decide if we should switch targets.
Switch to a different target if there's another potential target in range and current target is not. Restart the timer regardless.
We start a timer when the NPC passes beyond range
We refresh the timer whenever the NPC is close enough to the player
If the timer has stopped, and the player isn't too close, we switch to ranged
We start a timer when the NPC passes beyond its leash range
We refresh the timer whenever the NPC takes damage or is close enough to the player
If the timer has stopped, the leash position is far enough away, and the player isn't too close, we go home
